Comment: My read of Trump is that he doesn't form views based on conviction but on expediency. Every politician does that to some extent, but with Trump it seems to be pathological. He changed his view on abortion when he decided to run for president as a Republican. He changed his view on waterboarding because he no longer needs it as a campaign issue. The same is proving to be true of prosecuting Hillary Clinton, financing the border wall, etc.

Comment: One of the real issues here is the Colorado, even though the other watersheds are also issues. With the Colorado, we keep a certain amount, UNTIL the 2 main reservoirs, mead and powell, hit a certain level, and then we lose all of it. 
Both of these reservoirs continue to drop, rather than fill. As such, we are headed SOON to a time when we must give up all of our water, and NONE of our federal CONgress critters are doing a single thing about it. 
What is desperately needed, is for CONgress to push new nuclear reactors and require that all communities within 100 miles of the ocean,to use desalinated water. This is esp important in the west. Ideally, CONgress would actually help put in several pipelines to simply dump desalinated water into mead, so that it will simply use the current system in place. 
That is a 300 mile of piping, BUT, we have longer on oil/gas lines.

Comment: There are huge problems figuring out what values to use, how to assess them, and whether or not we want a 'values-based' national identity [the Americans call it a 'propositional nation'; another name would be 'state ideology']. I'd rather we didn't.

But here's the thing. Progress has removed from Canada any prospect of an ethnic national identity, or a cultural national identity based on common culture, or even a civic national identity based on loyalty to traditional institutions and statehood. All have been surpassed by events or actively declared racist by the left. Until nearly yesterday, a state ideology of progressive values basically WAS the leftist idea of Canada. Comment: There aren't many people who will deny that an increase in the minimum wage is disruptive and that this disruption will cause short term pain.

However, the study they cite to justify their claim of adverse consequences found no statistically significant effect on a three-year horizon. We have better ways of dealing with the effects of disruption than by delaying minimum wage increases. 

However, their entire argument misses the point. There are currently a great many pseudo-businesses being subsidized by the low level of the minimum wage - the shortfall between the minimum and a 'living wage' is picked up by government programmes such as rent-geared-to-income and by food banks, to name but two.

We need to eliminate these subsidies as quickly as possible. There will be pain as the pseudo-businesses find themselves unable to compete without subsidy, but the resources that are freed up will soon find a more productive use.

Comment: There is nothing for the feds to do here. The real estate problem is provincial.

And asking them to "be held accountable for policy that encourages inflow of overseas money" is backwards. Foreign investment is, mostly, a good thing. Certainly nobody complains when Google opens a Canadian engineering office or Ford upgrades its Oakville plant. Or, if capital inflows only offend you when they come from people who don't speak English, do you have a problem with Huawei staffing up a Waterloo research lab with ex-BlackBerry employees?

The real estate problem is because they are buying something that is needed locally and is inherently scarce. That creates a strong case for government intervention. But calling for Ottawa to enact broader policies against foreign investment amounts to killing the patient to cure the disease.

Comment: I grew up from birth until I was 10-years old in Shaktoolik, a village of about 150 people near Nome. Then, the village council was law and order. And it was obeyed Inupiat style. That was in the 1950s.

In the early 1970s, the State of Alaska decreed that villages were to become 2nd Class Cities, a departure from thousands of years of tried and true village governance. The SOA said if you want revenue sharing, you must follow what we say and do.

From then on, the village council no longer existed, and a ‚Äúcity‚Äù council took over turning to state laws as government decree. Village law and order, and thousands of years of experience, was dismantled.

As a child in Shaktoolik, the village council and those on it was the heartbeat of the community and everyone behaved as expected. Elders were on these councils and carried on. In my day, homicides and suicides and violent crimes were taboo and not to be condoned. Things have indeed changed for the worse.

Comment: Could you present some evidence of what you claim, first? For a denial to exist, there must be a credible case providing evidence. But, I am only aware of allegations that include no evidence or conclusions.
The few cases I recall involved:
- one person being murdered on a bridge by the Kremlin, whose murderers were caught - a pair of Muslims from Chechnya who vowed revenge for some policies they supported
- Anna Politkovskaya, who wrote in an obscure paper and had received many death threats over the years (I don't know what the outcome of the investigation was)
- Alexander Litvinenko, who drank polonium tea. And, that's all that's know.
If you have some evidence that suggests a conclusion for any of these things, maybe you ought to present it to authorities, so that allegations can be made, and so that social media commentators can start working on their responses to those allegations. You claiming you 'just know it,' like the "Russia hacking" claims, is not evidence.

Comment: The political reality is that the 11 largest states, with a majority of the U.S. population and electoral votes, rarely agree on any political question. The fact is that the big states are just about as closely divided as the rest of the country.  For example, among the four largest states, the two largest Republican states (Texas and Florida) generated a total margin of 2.1 million votes for Bush, while the two largest Democratic states generated a total margin of 2.1 million votes for Kerry.  
   
With National Popular Vote, it's not the size of any given state, it's the size of their "margin" that will matter.

Comment: Unfortunately, the system teaches public assistance recipients to be irresponsible with their PFD money. Comment: Hi Paul, 

Christa from Civil here. We need to work this into the FAQ, I think! 

The reason for the word count is that in testing we found that people simply weren't reading the entire comment if it was longer than about 1k characters. We suggest the "continued" method of posting (that is, creating a comment and then replying to yourself) in order to break up the thought and make sure that others actually read it. 

It turns out to be pretty convenient, too, because people can more easily comment on a specific part of your complete thought when it's separated in this way.

Comment: It is really impossible to know if this analyst is right or wrong. Any time a stock is breaking out on a technical basis, it is showing momentum that could turn into a multi-year stock run or more often than not, a trade that could last a few days or weeks. If you trade on this basis, you need to also be alert to the trade failing as many do and exit at the first sign of any one of these being a failing trade. Readers simply have little to no idea how successful these recommendations have been since we do not know which ones have been or would have been sold in the short term or held for the long term.  A successful trader holds winning stocks for as long as possible and exits losers as soon as possible.

Comment: A true UBI based system would be the start of the greatest period of innovation and advancement in human history - it would make the scientific revolution, industrial revolution and the space race all look like child's play. For the first time the FULL capacity for human genius could be utilized - no potential cancer curers would spend their lives mowing somebody's lawn because they were born poor. And because profitability is no longer a barrier to creativity, all human creativity can be explored. All possible art can be created, whether one fan or a billion loves it simply doesn't have to matter. A device only 100 people in the whole world would ever want - if it gets created at all today it costs millions and so the only time that happens is if it's useful to megacorps or very large government labs. 
But in a true UBI system - such devices will be available to order by those 100 people - for the cost of the materials.

Comment: Many? Most? voters want "choice" but settle for the known, rather than the unknown.  Here's hoping that voters now see the "unknown" is a better option, for, as Mike says, what we already know is pretty miserable.

Even if we have primaries, each major party nominates their incumbent, rather than a "new" name.  But even if we defeated all incumbents and voted for their successors (from either party), we would still have a dysfunctional Legislature.  Why? Because they are almost always cut from the same piece of partisan cloth.  New names; same tired philosophies.

Yes, it would be a risk to elect non-partisans/independents (as we did with Walker/Mallot).  But I've not seen W/M being any worse than the D/R office holders that preceded them.  At least they bring non-partisan ideas to the table.  So let's vote for those OTHER than D/R ... let's break away from the two-party (Tweedle Dee/Tweedle Dum) folks whose inaction and poor decision-making eventually got us into this mess.

Comment: I was a Maintenance Specialist, working at the Camp, when it was closed by the Sheriff's Office during one of our big lay-offs. I think that was in 2008? I was the last SO employee working there, and spent my time trying to keep up the place. The idea was to try to rent or lease the facility, but with the land zoning being for jail use, and the distance out in the woods, we did not get any serious offers. I kept the buildings up the best I could, with ventilation in all the rooms, fire prevention all around, grass cut and watered, all systems working, as well as security. Other employees worked security also, though they were no longer SO employees. With no renters, and no sign of re-opening for inmates, the Sheriff at the time said he would no longer pay for the upkeep, and turned it over to the regular County Parks Dept. After that, I think that maintenance was done only minimally. I put in my 40 per week, and still more was needed, but we had no budget. Hope it sells to someone!

Why are we spending $600+ billion a year on the most massive military machine the world has ever known( of which nukes make up a relatively small portion of that spending)? Comment: "zirconium pressure tubes hold the uranium fuel that splits into neutrons during fission. The tubes run horizontally through the core of the reactor (a.k.a. the calandria) and move the neutrons through hot, pressurized heavy water to a steam generator." Utter nonsense!
Journalists seem to have trouble explaining fission. Yes, each uranium atom splits into other elements, and in the process GIVES OFF neutrons, lots of them, and it only takes one to cause another uranium atom to split. The rest are absorbed; otherwise a nuclear explosion would ensue. Our Canadian reactors use deuterium oxide (heavy water) as the moderator, which gets so hot at those high pressures, that it can make ordinary water boil furiously and provide the 100's of megawatts of energy.

Comment: Ranked ballots for 13 candidates are not the same as counting one ballot only for one party.  The CPC leadership ballots allowed the ranking of  10 choices.  Each choice was assigned via postal code to one of 338 ridings.  Once assigned to the riding,  the top and  subsequent round top choices were  given a weighting and points for that riding based on the number who cast votes in that riding. This happened 10 times.  Through each iteration the Leadership Party Candidate with the least points was eliminated and their points apportioned equally to those candidates remaining.   So it's much more complicated  than the recent FPTP one-vote one-candidate recount here in BC.

Comment: Couple of things.

The lump sum always sounds good but Ted needs to determine if the amount of transfer (to a locked-in retirement savings plan) exceeds the maximum tax-sheltered transfer value. If it does the excess will be paid in cash and taxed as income.

Also is JS60% the only option? JS60% is the default in Ontario at least but normally DB plans also have the option of JS50% (which the spouse must agree to) and JS75% and JS100%. The reduction in pension for JS75% and JS100% is not as large as one may think.

Regardless, I disagree with advisor and would recommend that  Ted takes the DB pension. Best financial decision I ever made and my lump sum payout was well more than double Ted's, I also opted for JS75% which kept the missus happy. 

Remember, albeit with no inflation protection, the DB money is going to come in no matter what, whereas to generate a 4% return or whatever on investments has a risk element. (Of course, if the DB is from an iffy company take the lump sum).

Comment: This part of the TrumpCare plan is disturbing. I'm not sure why this is part of healthcare but...
"We're starting off... with essentially a giveaway to insurance executives," Levin said.
The proposed tax break, buried in cryptic language in the Republican plan, would allow health insurers to more fully deduct the value of their executives' compensation on their taxes. That compensation can be as high as tens of millions of dollars, in the case of CEOs of insurers.

Why a tax break for wages paid to a CEO of an insurance company?

Comment: That is not probable at all, as people like Ben Bernanke & Larry Summers have pointed out. For one thing, Glass-Steagall didn't apply to purely commercial banks like Wachovia & Washington Mutual that went bad on the basis of bad lending (which Monica alludes to). Similarly it didn't apply to AIG, an insurance company, which required massive bailouts. Summers has also pointed out (which Clinton relied on in the campaign) that most of the investment activity that caused the financial crisis was essentially shadow banking that, again, Glass-Steagall wouldn't have prevented. Further, Glass-Steagall would have actually prohibited the ultimate solution: large banks such as JP Morgan purchasing smaller, unstable firms in order to shore up their capital balances.

On the whole, I favor a reinstatement of some kind of Glass-Steagall, but because I think the Dodd-Frank regulations are hopelessly flawed in their complexity & favor larger banks over smaller.

Comment: Those programs are there for support, not to represent the victim through the court process. OVR is set up to represent the constitutional rights of the victims as attorneys. Victims for Justice can not represent victims as attorneys. How would you like it if defense counsel demanded your psych/medical records as a victim to try and claim you are not credible? Or to turn over your entire contents on your cell phone? This all becomes public record if granted, and mind you, it usually is. That is what OVR has been set up for, to ensure that the privacy and rights of the victims are upheld. The prosecution does not advocate for the victims, their only job is to notify if there is a hearing which they now source a third party program to do that. This program will only notify about certain hearings, and sometimes after the hearing has happened. Here is more about the constitutional rights for victims: https://ovr.akleg.gov/rights.php. Without OVR, this will fall by the wayside.

Comment: I don't quite follow what Kershaw is getting at. His thesis seems to be that some young generationals  in Vancouver and Toronto are unable to purchase a home because they lack sufficient income. I think most people would agree with that but it is nothing new. There have always been people priced out of these markets. The difference today is that an increasing number fall into this category. Why is that happening? The professor attributes it to wage disinflation and he may well be right to a degree but he does not address why the significant price inflation has taken place. Given the extreme competition for available housing, someone has managed to accrue the capital from somewhere. Generational population growth has remained relatively steady and new construction has been commensurate with that growth. Demand, however, is outstripping supply. This is because immigration growth is increasing at three times that of generational growth and many millennials can't compete with their wealth.

Comment: If I buy a bond the interest paid is based on what was agreed upon when I purchased it. Whether I choose to or not depends on what the interest vs. risk is. I might choose to buy a "junk" bond with high interest and associated risk or I might choose to invest in a bond paying low interest but with low risk. 

Likewise, companies choose to invest in order to get tax credits. Those tax credits spur investment far better than "tax cuts for the rich" because they're "targeted" toward infrastructure spending. The fiscal multiplier for infrastructure spending always outperforms "across the board" tax cuts. That's because wealthy investors put a portion of their money in bonds rather than spending it. I've done many sales presentations that discussed spending a half million to update corporate infrastructure. A $50,000 tax credit is an important selling point.

This is all pretty much standard fare from economists...

Waikele used to have these really huge boulders with Hawaiian "Glifs" carved in the boulders, when they "developed" (raped) Waikele, they hauled off the boulders with the Hawaiian glifs and crushed those.   We sat on those big boulders, drinking beers (cheapest ones from Longs, Primo, PBR), looking out at Pearl Harbor all the way to Honolulu.

Comment: LFS2, my 4 kW photovoltaic produces about 5 MWH per year.  In the winter, the output is pathetic.  Right now the 4000 W system is producing about 300 W.  In the summer much better with about 25 kWH per day with peak powers over 3 kW.  This amount of energy is worth about $250-$300/year.    In 25 years, the system might pay for itself, so no on a strictly financial basis, solar photovoltaic does not make sense here.  It might where power is more costly and sunshine is more plentiful.  I knew this going into it so I am paying for the feel good when I watch my net meter marking off the energy I feed back into the grid.  Yes, I think hydro is the best renewable energy by far.  Doesn't have to be dams.  Waterwheels in the Willamette should be good for 24/7 MW level power and they would not block the river.  Some laugh at water wheels, but moving water has a lot of energy and harvesting it is necessary to even think of scaling back carbon emission.

Comment: Humane euthanasia is faster and far more cost effective for ending the predation and disease spread by feral cats than is neutering.  Cats are not going extinct, but some of the species they kill are nearly extinct, and don't forget cats kill thru disease spread as well as by ripping and shredding the prey.  Cats are obligate carnivores and a waste of protein and resources.  I 100% support euthanasia of all feral cats and support mandatory neutering of owned cats prior to the first litter, with fines and penalties for failure to comply.  We need strict licensing laws for dogs and cats alike, with containment requirements, and mandatory microchipping, so ownership and vaccinations can be registered.  If you love feral cats, then be a responsible adult about it and keep them at your place and use a containment fence, neuter, license, register, deflea, deworm, and keep vaccination records accurately.  Euthanasia is a better choice and is humane for the cat and saves wildlife.

Comment: Thank you for an excellent column. I would, however, like to add a further perspective. In Canada, tax money has followed the child since the Quebec Act of 1774. In Alberta, for example, tax money follows students to Catholic, private, and other sectarian (e.g., Dutch Reformed) schools, as well to district-run and charter public schools.  Students in all of these schools must meet provincial standards, which are assessed in 3rd (optional), 6th and 9th grade (the Province's highest level assessment is PISA). There is an integrated provincial curriculum, along with student, parent, and teacher guides. Schools have the option not to use them. But every year, every school's value-added results (achievement growth above what student demographics would predict) is widely published, and most parents use to make their school choices. So what people here in the US call a "voucher" system can, in fact, work well. But multiple design factors are critical to its success.

Comment: Renewables have two fundamental flaws in them that have been with us since the turn of the last century. First off they are not reliable as base load generation. When a KW is needed on the demand grid, it must instantly be generated for that demand or the lights don't come on. The regulated power base that we all pay for has to double the investment for back up generation such as natural gas fired processes for wind farms. Secondly they are enormously expensive. Wind and solar are heavily subsidized by tax payers and utility rate payers. Wind alone subsidies  in a $2.50/mmbtu natural gas market amount to $6.25/mmbtu in real cost. this is a fact that is conveniently ignored. This hurts Xcel and their power customers because as the rates for power go up, demand destruction kicks in and Xcel is not selling as much power as they need to grow their business to stay in business. Coal will continue to be a huge part of India and China because they are emerging economies and need cheap energy

Comment: Customary for a serious article is to define the word first. What is 'reform'? The essence of a 'reform' is that it corrects an injustice or defect. Westminster-style democracy is not based on national parties in parliaments; it's based on single members of Parliament, who win election because their votes were more numerous than, say, the 10 people who ran against them. Other 'reforms' would be to correct seat distribution by adjusting to population shifts. 
Since the only people who want this "changed" are the losers, why are we even calling this 'reform'? I call it moving the goalposts.

Comment: The unique aspect of it right now is that Oregon stands alone, and therefore can reap some benefits of national pricing. That benefit goes away as more states join, so there is less incentive as more states pass a tax like this. So the question is how many states would pass the law. I don't think states with a high corporate tax burden would pass it because those companies would be hurt by the extra tax burden (note, the "free money" you mention is from the perspective of the consumer, but the corporate perspective does come into play... the current Oregon corporate tax burden is moderate to low but that is not true for many other states) and the pushback would be greater in current high corporate tax states. I think my analysis is pretty well reasoned and bias from partisanship is also moderate to low! :-)

I think statements that we'll all pay 2.5% more is a much more partisan view. I can't see how that would be true at all when .25% of companies have more than $25M in sales.

Comment: I'm involved in the study mentioned by Dr Little. I also use a keto diet for patients in my medical practice who have insulin resistance, diabetes, any CNS condition, dyslipidemia or inflammatory problem. A keto diet is beneficial for all of the above. I don't share my colleague's caveat about keto. There is plenty of good information on the net now so that virtually anyone can do the diet without getting into trouble. People on meds for blood pressure or blood sugar have to be careful as the diet will reduce or eliminate their need for these. The best reference is dietdoctor.com. My good friend, Dr Andreas Eenfeldt, a Swedish MD, has developed a very comprehensive and useful guide for low-carb and keto ways of eating and - bonus - it's in English. The Atkins diet is keto in it's early phase and is not high protein. This is a common misconception (full disclosure, I'm on their Scientific Advisory Board).  My family has been eating keto for 15 years. We wouldn't have it any other way.

Comment: I've read these renewable jobs claims in the past and would like to see a more detailed analysis of what constitutes a renewable job vs a fossil fuel job. I'm quite sure installing solar panels on a roof would be a renewable job, so does installing asphalt shingles count as fossil fuel job?

I recently read an article that claimed that total renewable energy jobs outnumbered fossil fuel jobs. The latest electrical generation figures from the EIA from 2015 break down the US 4 trillion kilowatts market like this, coal 33%, natural gas 33%, nuclear 20%, hydro 6%, petroleum 1%, renewables other than hydro 7% (wind 4.7%, biomass 1.6%, solar .6%, geothermal .4%). These figures do not even take into consideration the energy used by the transportation industry which almost exclusively relies on fossil fuels.

So based on the statistical analysis of the watts, btu or joules of energy per job, fossil fuels, if they truly are fewer in number, deliver a vastly superior return to the consumer.

Comment: Niedzvieki didn't resign or get into trouble because of what he wrote, as an individual free writer.

Comment: Something to ponder.  In March 2016, Japan Rail Corporation opened its Shinkansen (bullet train) line linking the islands of Honshu and Hokkaido.  The dual track line is 149 kilometers long (92.5 miles) and runs 23% on viaducts (21.2 miles), 4% on bridges (3.7 miles), and 65% in tunnels (62 miles) and it cost was 550.8 billion yen ($4.67 billion).  That is about $50.4 million per mile.  HART, if it ever gets finished, will be 20 miles long and at current estimates will cost $500 million per mile, or ten times more per mile than it cost the Japanese to build its new Hokkaido line.  New York‚Äôs East Side Access is 6 miles in a tunnel.   Current cost estimate is $10.2 billion or $1.7 billion per mile, or 34 times more than the Japanese rail project.  Yes, there are differences in labor and materials cost between the three locations, but 10 and 34 times more?  I do think so.  It seems to me HART and NYC hired the wrong people for their rail projects.

Comment: Understood, but I'm aware of none that seeks the unique entitlements claimed by TWU: (1) the right to retain taxpayer supported charitable status while stipulating a test of faith for anyone seeking to avail of that charity, together with (2) a flow-through authority that would compel the guardians of our legal profession to admit to its ranks persons whose legal training embodies a core principle that, on its face, would deny equality rights to a particular class of Canadians. 

Religious institutions are undoubtedly entitled to promote their articles of faith within their spheres of influence. But that's not the same as saying beliefs which are inherently discriminatory should be given a back door into (i.e. legitimacy in) our judicial system. 

I suspect the court will be swayed by the simplicity of the fix: that if TWU wants to ensure its graduates are deemed fit for admission to the bar, it will remove the odious covenant. It leaves TWU free to proselytize to its heart's content.

Comment: Like the nation's capital, the Canada Day morning festivities in St. John's took place in the rain. But it didn't dampen enthusiasm for Canada's 150th in its newest province. 

We were among the few who arrived soaking wet at the 6 AM sunrise ceremonies at Cabot Tower atop Signal Hill via the North Head Trail. The trail is less daunting than it looks but a good way to work up an appetite for the free breakfast a couple of hundred feet below at the interpretation centre. We appreciated the St. Pat's Irish Dancers and other musical groups who entertained us while we feted on sausage and egg overlooking the oldest city in North America. 

After drying out, we took in the Beaumont Hamel ceremonies at the War Memorial before heading to the free concert at the head of Quidi Vidi Lake. Followed that with a delectable duck dinner at Saltwater on Duckworth Street, capped with an iceberg vodka martini amid the fireworks back at the lake.

Golding is right. Pretty cool, inspiring place.

Comment: I believe that if they laid out a detailed framework for proceeding with electoral reform and ultimately concluded that it was not feasible to deliver in time for the next election, that would be one thing. 

But after campaigning on this topic as a significant plank - and with over two thirds of votes in the last election cast for parties that had electoral reform as an unambiguous, front-page promise - this bunch is now saying it's not important. And that is rubbish. Failing to deliver on electoral reform prior to the next election is one thing. Selling out a significant campaign promise and supporting a status quo that results in government that does not come close to reflecting voting will (less than 40% of votes should NEVER garner you an unchallenged majority).

And I am saying this as someone who has been a federal LPC supporter and would be very likely to support them after electoral reform as well. But not if they mess this up. 

Inaction is unacceptable. This is fundamental.

Comment: You show hypocrisy by condemning democratic-socialism when you support "public roads, armies, infrastructure." Congress approved the first public road in 1806 funded with taxes: a form of socialism. Not all taxpayers used the road, but their money funded it. Strict capitalists would have refused and relied on privately owned roads. The Military is funded with taxes, even if a taxpayer in Alaskan wilderness never uses it: a form of socialism. Strict capitalists would refuse and rely on private armies. A state builds a dam to power a city using taxes from people who never visit that city--a form of socialism. Strict capitalists would rely on private generators. Any reasonable person can't denounce democratic-socialist programs as radical and also claim they are inherent to and necessary for our society. Twist your words as much as you wish, but the redistribution of taxes into public programs regardless if the individual taxpayer uses them is by definition a form of democratic-socialism.

Comment: You are correct that value judgments of right and wrong are human constructs and thus are totally subjective. However, precisely because they are human constructs, how would you expect to apply them to nonhuman animals? Just because all animals can feel pain and suffer does not mean that non-human animals can think or reason in a way that might reduce their pain in the future or the pain that they might inflict on other animals in their effort to survive.

The bear is not getting a free pass because it is not sentient, but because we cannot change the habit of the bear or talk to a bear to convince it to be a vegetarian without being able to converse with it (and perhaps we would not want to change its habit). Sentience has nothing to do with the bear's inability to exchange ideas with humans.

Humans have the ability to think about how we can change the way we do things in the future - animals, as far as we know, do not, or at least on a very limited basis.

So I don't see your point.

Comment: Oh I have no doubt that many did. The (R) nomination was wide-open for the first month (with a whopping 17 candidates in the race all diluting each other's votes).  And the (D) nomination was considered a slam dunk for Hillary for a year leading up to the primaries, and through the first month of them.  

It wasn't until March 5 (about 20 primaries into the race) that it suddenly started becoming a race on the (D) side, when Bernie surprised with 5 primary wins that week.  By then, Trump had taken control of the (R) delegate count by winning most of the early states, most of which were open primaries. Comment: While these proposed measures come no way close to compensating for the loss of a loved one, we hope such an increase in penalties for those responsible for vehicular homicides in Ontario will help drive debate in our upcoming provincial election, and that we will soon have laws that seek to more reasonably protect vulnerable road users, and law-abiding motorists alike.

The problem is much larger than most in our automobile dependent province want to admit, but the world is changing around us on this issue and we will only be left further behind if we continue to pretend that toxically-fuelled highway-capable motor vehicles are the wisest tools for most urban jobs and point-to-point local journeys.

Many rational changes to the way we move in modern cities are coming. 

This overdue announcement by the current Government of Ontario indicates that even the out-of-touch Liberals have been moved to act by the growing groundswell of public outrage in urban centres in and around Toronto.

Comment: Only one country in history has ever successfully made a significant reduction in drug addiction. In fact they achieved more than a 90% drop in heroine addiction. And they did it by doing the one thing no other country has had the courage to do: decriminalizing all drugs and treating addiction as a public health problem, not a crime.
In Portugal if you're caught with heroine (or any other illegal drug), you are paid a visit - not by the police but by a social worker. The social worker will run you through a questionaire to guage your level of use and risk factors. Then - reccomend a (completely free and completely voluntary) treatment program - which you may make use of if you are so inclined.
The free treatment programs are of the class of top private institutions - fully funded by money saved on trying to police the unpoliceable, attendence is truly voluntary, nobody *has* to go -but everybody who wants to, can.

We should copy that program. It's the only one in history that worked.

Comment: No. My respect is for fundamental principles applying to all legal systems, not to canon law which needs serious reform. As a matter of theory, a legal system can pass retrospective laws, making criminal what was not criminal before. But it is a practice that is banned under International Covenant on Civil and Political Rights, and, as you say under some constitutions. There is no need to ban canon law any more than there is a need to ban the rules of golf. Civil law ignores canon law when it requires anyone to disobey the civil law. One of the problems with this whole issue of reporting is that most countries do not have comprehensive reporting laws, so that in failing to report abuse, the bishops were not breaking any civil law. And they were obeying the pontifical secret under canon law. France did have such reporting laws, and until 2010, canon law required it to be broken, as Cd Castrillon confirmed in 2001.

Comment: There is that possibility, one example would be over reliance on terrain elevation data bases. Lat/Long info tends to be pretty accurate but elevation is notoriously wrong as it is much harder to generate accurate data in the first place. 200 foot errors are common in my experience and have been cited as strong possibilities in more than one crash where impact was just below ridge lines, etc. As late as the early 2000's we had "busts" in very expensive elevation models used to install microwave paths, that 200 foot class error was rampant.  Today there are extensive efforts at updating models to far higher accuracies.  An important element would be "truth" testing routes in clear weather to validate data.  The best strategy is to stay out of the soup in the first place,  Dr Jerry Cockrell articulated a whole series on the how's and why's of human behavior relating to aviation safety.  In the '80s.  They were a true gem, informative with catchy humor.  Priceless.

Comment: True, JR, Jonah should be ashamed of his misuse of health statistics here.  While he correctly notes that life expectancy can be affected by lifestyle, he fails to note the obvious--  that there is a better stat than this to estimate comparative quality of national health care:
The infant mortality rate.  (the number of babies who die within their first year per 1000. born)
In this one we do even worse.  According to the CIA's list of  all 225 countries (even tiny ones)  we rank 56, or about 32 looking at only the larger nations, coming in between Serbia and Bosnia Herzogovina.
Our IM s est. for 2016 was 5.8.  The world leader (other than Monaco) was Japan 
-at 2.0.  In short, an American baby was almost three times as likely to die as a Japanese one.
After Japan came Iceland 2., Norway 2.5, etc.  Denmark was 4.
And poor miserable Afghanistan was last at 112.8

But it should be noted that family lifestyle certainly is important, with Scandinavia and Asia probably being superior.

Comment: Not really.
Wikipedia, "war powers act"
"The War Powers Resolution (also known as the War Powers Resolution of 1973 or the War Powers Act) (50 U.S.C. 1541‚Äì1548) is a federal law intended to check the president's power to commit the United States to an armed conflict without the consent of the U.S. Congress."

It only allows "that the U.S. President can send U.S. Armed Forces into action abroad only by declaration of war by Congress, "statutory authorization," or in case of "a national emergency created by attack upon the United States."

First strike is therefore prohibited (but has been violated by probably every President since at least Regan).  Mattis seems to be indicating there is no limit to the President's power and only "perhaps" Congress has say.

Comment: Points from my article in Celebration: 1) 15% of the population suffers from mild to moderate hearing loss. 50% of those over 75. 2) God is present in the Word and in the Eucharist. We would be outraged at a parish that tolerated barriers keeping physically handicapped from receiving. Yet we fall short in eliminating barriers that keep 15% of the congregation from hearing. 3) Immediate fixes include training lectors, celebrants, and homilists to speak less rapidly, enunciate clearly, and use microphones properly. A Hearing loop won't fix a garbled word. 4) When necessary, qualified sound professionals should be engaged. Acoustics should be part of each church design. I can point to examples where it wasn't. 5) Parish health ministries should be involved. Health risks associated with hearing loss include heart attacks, strokes, dementia and increased risks of falling. Spiritual and emotional dangers include resentment, fear, social isolation and family disruption.

Comment: My personal experiences in Cuba ( 2 holidays there), one shortly after the Russian economic pullout and the other about 10 years later, were revelatory. The former revealed the true squalor and poverty of the people, without any apparent lose of dignity. I had frank  conversations with a number of Cubans of varying ages (soto voce) and the unanimous view seemed to be that Castro was a hero,   having liberated the island from the violent, corrupt grasp of US puppet Batista and the Mafia, but he stayed on too long and his economic policies were just downright bad. There was no aura of fear hanging over the place that I could discern although clearly one would be foolish to broadcast dissent to any degree.  By the time of my second visit to Cuba, the place I had stayed was unrecognizable; gone the empty shelves, the impoverished classrooms the unpaid teachers, the tourist sex trade. The benefits of the tourist trade had clearly been passed on to, Cuban citizens.  I said, Ole for Castro!

Comment: Actually, you can not find shrines like those on Mauna Kea "everywhere on the island where there are stackable rocks."   The uprights that I mentioned in point 3 of my last comment are distinctive and unusual.  In addition to Mauna Kea, shrines with similar uprights are found on Nihoa and Mokumanamana in the northwest Hawaiian Islands, and at one structure at `Ilio Point on Moloka`i.  They are not found other places in the Hawaiian Islands.

Similar shrines are also found in the Tuamotu and Society Islands, which is one reason archaeologists are particularly interested in them, and perhaps a factor in why the protectors are making the claim the mountain is sacred.

Archaeologists are confident these shrines are ancient, but recognize that their ideas are fallible.  If you have information that the many dozens of shrines with upright stones on Mauna Kea are recently made, please share it.

Comment: Hi, Recluse100...thanks so much for the "Liberals under Louis St. Laurent saw fit to ban "crime comics" statement.  I had no idea!  So, I did 15 minutes digging.

#1: Banning comics wasn't a Liberal government cause.  It was a Conservative member's cause.  So, St. Laurent, while PM, had no influence.
 
#2: The 1949 "ban" was a private members bill by Conservative MP (Kamloops, BC) E. Davie Fulton, who went on to be Minister of Justice in the 1957 John Diefenbaker government.

#3: Fulton was influenced the work of Victoria, BC anti-comic crusader Eleanor Gray, the school district's Parent Teacher Council (the USA's  "PTA") and the actions of two Dawson Creek kids.  The kids stole a rifle, shot at a passing car--killing the passenger.  BC people were shocked. Social Services discovered (uh-oh!) the kids had stacks of...CRIME COMICS!  

#4 Fulton's criminal code revision--Bill 10--was passed and censorship became law, despite the comic industry's efforts.

Amazing stuff...thanks again.

Comment: Meggsy,  BC;s allowable annual cut, from Timber supply areas and area-based TFL's is about 72 million m3 per year. Of that a few million m3 is exported under permit, primarily via the surplus test for harvested timber. 

Those big green forests out there are not the vast repository of huge, uniformly straight and sound giant logs you think they are.  A typical stand of coastal timber will contain several species and dozens of grades of logs ranging from almost fully decayed stems to large clear sawlogs.   Sawmills, veneer plants and pulp/paper mills do not ever and cannot consume all these grades, particularly if no market exist for the output.  In that case rafts of logs are advertised for sale and if not taken may be exported.   If you're going to hate an industry, get your facts staright

Comment: What Trudeau should consider is a maximum income for corporate employees. I don't think we should or could cap the income of sole proprietors or partners, but corporations are created by law and enjoy protections not covered by private ownership.
 
A CEO sets the executive compensation package and reward executives with huge pay raises, as what's happened in the past 30 years, is really robbing from the shareholder. And a CEO with a salary of $5 million should not be paid more than, say, $500 thousand. The savings would then be used to hire more workers or added to the shareholder's dividend.

Too many mergers and acquisitions happen only to justify a CEO getting a pay raise. They don't add to share value and often the shareholder sees a decline in value of both stock and dividend while the cost is absorbed. Sometimes there's never a payoff. 

Frankly, Adam Smith said the Free Market only works if  there are many similar-sized firms. We don't see that now. Near monopolies are the norm.

Comment: Another misleading, alarmist headline from the G&M. Simply put, this is a short term glitch and cannot be viewed as an indicator of the future trend.  It will take at least a year to confirm whether manufacturing GDP is contracting or continuing to grow.

Comment: We need to improve funding if we want high quality public schools, not remove funding and send it to private schools. The benefits of school vouchers have been vastly overstated for years, while their problems and the damage they could do are ignored.

Vouchers neither improve academic scores, nor provide an advantage for low or middle income families. They do not lead to increased access to private schools, but they do damage low and middle income public schools by depriving them of students and the associated funding per student.
The decrease in funding becomes a cycle, with funding chopping into performance, leading to withdraws, leading to reduced funding, leading to poorer performance, etc etc etc.

Comment: Domesticated cats (Felis catus) never existed in nature anywhere on earth.  They have differentiated at the species level from their nearest relative and parent species, the Eurasian wild (or forest) cat (F. sylvestris).  F. catus is definitely NOT "non-GMO".  They have been subject to intense selective breeding and ruthless culling for millennia.  They have fewer teeth, smaller brains, longer gut (an adaptation for digesting human-proffered low-protein food), and are overall 25-50% smaller than F. sylvestris.  They are also less territorial and breed 2-3 times more often than their wild forebear.  And they kill by reflex--their killing and feeding impulses are governed by separate regions of their little brains.  We bred them that way.

And what is truly amazing is that these profound physical and physiological changes could have derived from intense BEHAVIORAL-driven selective breeding in as little as half a century:

Comment: White, Sitka and Lutz (a cross between white and sitka) are all vulnerable to insect attack.  the preceding environmental conditions govern to what degree a tree is vulnerable.  For example, the Sitka spruce in seward escaped destruction in the Kenai outbreak, while the Sitka spruce in Homer was utterly devastated.  Most of the trees taken down in the outbreak were Lutz spruce

Beetles have two main factors that govern what tree to attack:  1: the size of the tree (bigger tree=thicker bark material=more food)  and 2: the ability of the tree to generate the Pitch and Plant Secondary compounds required to mount a successful defense, which can be affected by both the tree's age, as well as the environmental conditions (drought, low nutrients, etc), and preexisting diseases such as fungus.

I've heard a few researchers suggest that Lutz are more vulnerable than either Sitka or White, but at the tip of the spear, the size and health of a tree are bigger factors.

Comment: Any state that enacts a proportional approach on its own would reduce its own influence. 

If states were to ever start adopt a proportional approach on a piecemeal basis, each additional state adopting the approach would increase the influence of the remaining states and thereby would decrease the incentive of the remaining states to adopt it. A state-by-state process of adopting a proportional approach would quickly bring itself to a halt, leaving the states that adopted it with only minimal influence in presidential elections.

The National Popular Vote bill is the way to make every person's vote equal and matter to their candidate because it guarantees that the candidate who gets the most votes in all 50 states and DC becomes President.

Comment: Odd comment about letting 'the articles of the Confederation prevail", moon howler.

"Differences in relative population sizes between Ontario, Quebec and the Maritime Provinces at the time of Confederation resulted in the adoption of ‚Äúrepresentation by population,‚Äù or voter equality, as the guiding principle of representation in the House of Commons. Comment: Why would we lower taxes?  Federal income taxes in the U.S. are not high, either historically for the country or compared to other developed countries. Social Security and Medicare taxes, which are already dedicated to those programs, comprise an ever increasing % of total Federal tax collections, while individual and corporate income taxes (most particularly corporate) have declined steeply as a % Federal tax receipts.  This is basic information, you can obtain it with 10 minutes on Google and 15 more minutes examining the data.  "Lower taxes" is a bumper sticker for the supply-side economics crowd, who have failed the U.S. miserably.  Tax cuts for the wealthy while our infrastructure crumbles around us and the rest of the world out-educates our youth.

Comment: While it's important that the administration take public opinion into account-- we are a democracy, after all -- I am not sure that these micro-polls are the best way of doing it.

First, all polls have inherent bias.  Selection of subject and the wording of questions help predetermine outcomes whether the pollster concsiously applies his/her viewpoint or not.

Second, polls will only report on the opinions of those who are willing to participate. Many of us never answer calls unless they are from numbers we recognize, since discount cruise offers are annoying; many others are simply too busy.  

These factors result in a high degree of inaccuracy.  Neither Trump's win nor Trudeau's majority was predicted by polling.

If the PCO really wants the pulse of  the nation, they would do better to monitor sites like this and have their MPs conduct the odd town hall style meeting.  The people who genuinely care about issues are the ones that take part in these activities.

Comment: The Chinese Central Bank purchases large quantities of dollar assets such as US Treasury Bills. This demand for dollars increases the value of the dollar compared to the Chinese yuan. If the Chinese sold its dollar assets and saved the money in China, the dollar would depreciate and the Chinese currency appreciate. Therefore, to maintain a weak exchange rate, the Chinese need to keep buying dollar assets. In order to make their goods more competitive, Asian currencies have been forced to devalue to a lower rate vs the US dollar than the yuan. It's basic economics.

The problem with a weak currency is it creates inflationary pressure. Since China is a big importer of commodities, a weaker exchange rate increases the cost of living and the cost of raw materials. As result, the Chinese Government has allowed a small appreciation in the exchange rate to help mitigate inflationary pressure. They have done this by trying to diversify away from the US dollar, but they still buy dollars.

Comment: And the most efficient.  

All depends on what you're talking about.  From the standpoint of moving the most people in the least amount of space, yes, transit is more efficient.  But if as an individual you need to get from anywhere to anywhere else, transit is usually GROSSLY inefficient (taking forever with multiple transfers and waiting times, if it even gets anywhere close at all).  

That's where this "transit vs cars" debate is usually so far off base, because it's usually apples vs oranges.  If you're only going between a few limited and very specific spots where transit happens to serve that route when you need it, then yes, it's often more efficient.  But for nearly everything else, no, it's not.

10 U.S. Code ¬ß 311 - Militia: composition and classes
(a) The militia of the United States consists of all able-bodied males at least 17 years of age and, except as provided in section 313 of title 32, under 45 years of age who are, or who have made a declaration of intention to become, citizens of the United States and of female citizens of the United States who are members of the National Guard.

Comment: It is time people stop accepting the nonsensical criticism of "its political" or defending an action by saying "this isn't political." Education is the core of democratic politics and being a decent person.  Art is always political, it either celebrates the status quo or challenges it.  Both are needed in any healthy society. What this congressman means is that the films don't support his political agenda of marginalizing people who are different from him. Comment: Nope.

To be eligible for Canadian citizenship, you must have been physically present in Canada as a permanent resident for at least 1,460 days (4 years) in the six years immediately before the date of your application.  

There are other conditions set out at s. 5(1) of the Citizenship act including  being physically present in Canada for at least 183 days during each of four calendar years that are fully or partially within the six years before the application and file a return of income in respect of four taxation years that are fully or partially within the six years before the application.

And it will take a minimum of one year process a citizenship application assuming everything goes 
smoothly.

In the US you must have been a legal alien resident (green card holder) for five years prior to submitting a citizenship application.  For immigrants married to U.S. citizens, from green card to U.S. citizenship will take around three years.  Canada has no such dispensation for spouses

Comment: Peak oil is very real. This is true of any non-renewable resource, particularly energy resources in which the return on energy invested is a hard ceiling (gold can be valued arbitrarily highly but a barrel of oil cannot be worth more than the energy put into finding, extracting, and refining it).

To be fair, cartoonishly oversimplified versions of M. King Hubbert's hypothesis have become the norm these days. But in his 1948 to 1956 published papers, Hubbert, a oil company geophysicist with a prior background in mineral exploration, used reasonably accurate estimates of known and inferred global fossil fuel resources, stated that advances in technology could lengthen profitable production, made it clear that the "Hubbert curve" was not a simple symmetric bell curve and that it applied to individual production fields, which cumulatively and collectively would approximate a similar curve on national and global scales.

Comment: Hello Wholesome,

Actually, at this point with what little is known, I would not label this yet as an act of terrorism.

There is  no universally accepted definition of terrorism, but probably the most useful definition requires three things:

1. Perpetrator holds ideological goals they demand be implemented upon society in the way of official policy.

2. Perpetrator intentionally seeks, as victims, civilian non-combatants.

3. Perpetrator has access to non-violent options as recourse, but choses to not use them.

At this point there is zero evidence - none - regarding requirement number one, above.

By that (very reasonable) definition, Sandy Hook (the school slaughter) was not an act of terrorism. Today's attack may prove to be another Sandy Hook. 

And, by the way, by that (very reasonable) definition, some of the attacks against soldiers in recent years were also not acts of terrorism, though they were strangely labeled as such by the media (see item two in above definition).

Comment: I don't propose or support raising user fees at JUST the rural transfer sites.  I do think the County needs to take a look at a) having commercial haulers go directly to Short Mountain instead of Glennwood (Glennwood is a "transfer site", meaning the trash is handled twice...first dumped by haulers then transferred by the County) and b) looking at the percentage of the trash generated by commercial haulers and the revenue from them...  certainly, increased cost would be "passed through" to the customers, but that is fairer  than a county subsidy for those residents who use those commercial haulers.  

I think this issue involved another of those urban/rural conflicts and balancing services and costs.  If we rural users drive to Glennwood, or in my case Bolton Road in Veneta, we have the tipping fee, the fuel cost and the time.  For those "up river", how much extra would seem fair to have a closer transfer site and avoid the longer trip?  Such a "surcharge" might help some....

Comment: If you read up on history, you will see that lobotomies and eugenics were not actually based on science.  The lobotomy was a primitive treatment that seemed outwardly to work (to effectively silence the mentally ill) but only because others would no longer see or hear the effects of the sick.  There was no science behind it, and it was done in  a time when there was little scientific understanding of mental illness.  Mental health medicine was still in the "dark ages" then.  As the science progressed, lobotomies were discontinued.

Eugenics was a belief system that had no basis in science, although there were those who famously tried to use science to justify their belief.  They failed to do so, BTW.

As matt calgary correctly responded, electro-convulsive therapy is a valid treatment that is still used today.  It is true though that it was overused in the past, for the same reasons that lobotomies were used...lack of scientific knowledge.

Science is evidence based.

Comment: The essay by Spadaro and Figueroa raises an interesting question: how does one change public opinion in our Church? In 2015, Pope Francis spoke to Congress and, through them, to the American people.  He spoke of great Americans -- Lincoln, Day, Merton, King. In 2016, we elected Mr. Trump. 
In 2014 and 2015, Pope Francis gathered the bishops of the world into a synod to discuss the family, then wrote an Apostolic Exhortation, Amoris Laetitia, to focus our ideas and energies on divine mercy. But the divisions among us appear to grow deeper. 
I think Pope Francis has tried everything he knows to bring about change, but we and our world have become so resistant to everything but what we want to hear, it all falls on deaf ears. Being deaf, I know how that feels. Until someone comes along who can give us a new language, a way of signing perhaps, that can replace the old ways of speaking to ourselves, I don't see how any of this will change.

Comment: I'm pretty certain that Germany is well past the economic instabilities and power-grabbing Nazi leftovers of the late-1940s/early-1950s that required that the Germans be "kept down".  If Europe was worried about such things, they'd have never let Germany into the EU where their economic and technological influence could achieve the same goals as a strong military did 80 years ago.

Further, why assume that any one nation would have to build up a military to defend the rest of Europe?  NATO was a European idea based on mutual self-defense - so that one nation never rose to that level and so that they could defend themselves against the Soviets.  Their task is to work toward a mutual capability, not hide under the shadow of one superpower.  But, if they were to allow Germany to grow to that level and hid behind the Germans (much like they currently do with the US), would that not be their own decision to make regardless of what the rest of the world thinks?

Comment: An excellent article, however missing the fact that models are already working elsewhere in the world that clearly show 1) government shouldn't be involved in Transport, and 2) Transport is a total revenue opportunity for government, not an 'obligation' or 'expense line'.
City of Toronto's (not the GTA!) and Hong Kong's population density are actually similar. Toronto has half the population and area of Hong Kong. Hong Kong loses US$1 billion annually operating its public transit. Sounds familiar. But Hong Kong's Metrolinks equivalent, the MTR Corp, has *net* US$2 billion profit, of which HK Gov't gets US$1.5 billion in dividends (it owns of 75% of MTR Corps shares - the rest trade on the stock market). So HK has *no* transport costs and US$1.5 billion to boot. Plus corporate taxes too. 
You can't always get a profit, but you can always reduce the costs. Corporations are 1,000x better at this than governments and should be let lose to save cities from their politicians and budget woes.

Comment: I kind of disagree on this point... building taller does not imply the best of densification.

Paris France is incredibly dense, yet few buildings are over 7 or 8 floors high.  Similar case in Washington DC where no buildings can be taller than the Washington Monument

As a Torontonian, it is my own personal opinion that the glorification of height, at the expense of all else, has led to urban canyons devoid of the street life that creators of density crave to have. People don't feel connected to street life when they can shut themselves away on the 40th floor of a building. Also, if you've ever tried to sit out on a balcony on a 40th floor apt suite, then you know it can be as unpleasant as all heck with the dusty wind gusts that permeate the upper floors of too-tall towers.

If developers gave more thought towards preserving a neighbourhood feel, as opposed to foisting 50, 60 or 70 storey towers to replace 2 and 3 storey streetfronts, then I believe there'd be much less opposition.

Comment: I believe my memory on this is accurate. Insurance companies are regulated by the states with varying degrees of scrutiny. This shouldn't be such a difficult thing to understand. Climate science is quite familiar with the array of factors influencing climate, both natural and anthropogenic. Attribution of warming or cooling for any period relies on a comprehensive analysis of all of the factors acting upon the climate over that period. We look at solar activity, volcanism and albedo changes, teleconnections and ocean current changes, land use impacts and carbon cycle changes, changes in atmospheric composition, and more. Several such analyses have found that the anthropogenic warming contribution since the mid 20th century is actually over 100% with natural and some anthropogenic factors yielding offsetting cooling. That's simply what all of the evidence points to.

Comment: You listed reasons why a big company is bad for competitors. Yes, the muscle and economy of scale of a big business is hard to counter if you're small. But the reason they're big and you're small is that they have more customers, because they deliver the right combination of prices, quality and convenience. Competing head-on with a large company that has happy customers is very hard, but when those customers become unhappy, there is room for new competition to arise. All of this is rough on the small competitors, but serves up exactly what consumers demand, as expressed by where they spend their money.

Comment: A low-barrier shelter, which accepts people who are addicted to alcohol and other drugs, is desperately needed in Eugene.  Egan Warming Centers are low-barrier, with people accepted into church-based shelters so long as their behavior is not disruptive.  Since the warming centers only open when the night temperature drops below 30 degrees, this low-barrier sheltering of people who are homeless literally saves lives.  Run totally by volunteers, the Egan centers demonstrate that it is possible to provide low-barrier shelter for all types of people, including those not admitted into The Mission due to its rules.  A year-round shelter tied into social service providers and addiction treatment programs would be a major step toward the reduction of homelessness in Eugene, assuming there are even greater efforts on the part of the City to provide affordable housing for those in need.  The latter is critical to homelessness reduction for all who are unhoused.

Comment: It's actually not an "archaic" system at all.  It's doing exactly what it is supposed to do - namely keeping the island community intact and safe from Bay Street execs, house flippers, and other profiteers.
It works perfectly.

The community over there is vibrant and alive - and most of all, it's affordable to the folks who grew up there - unlike the rest of Toronto.

The prices aren't what the article says.  They basically work out to what it would cost to build the house today, minus depreciation.  So, if you keep your house repaired, and make improvements, that value is maintained.  You loose nothing.  

It is, however, not at all suitable for flippers, speculators, and profiteers - which is perfect, imho.  None of those people know the first thing about living in a community. 

 If you buy a house there it's because you want to live there - not because you're trying to extract profit.

Comment: I also have never had a gun pointed at me. I have been in a training environment wherein every single person, hundreds of them including children age 12 and older, were armed, much of the time with fully loaded handguns. I felt perfectly comfortable.
However, I understand your concern about every armed person making the right choice in the use of deadly force, especially those afflicted with mental/emotional, prejudicial, and disability issues. And yes, there are those who spoil for a fight and those who accept the invitation to fight.
In the gun culture circles in which I associate, our mantra is, the best gun fight is the one that never happened. Conflict avoidance and escape, if at all possible, is best. Only in the case of there being no escape, and wherein an attack is clearly imminent, the attacker has the means, the attack would likely result in serious injury or death, AND there has been no incitement on the part of the victim(s) is the use of deadly force lawful by civilians.

Comment: I retired at 53 not too long ago (I have passive income generated from an online business), and I'll be doggoned if I will ever work ever again. You couldn't pay me enough to take a job. I hope I have many decades ahead of being totally free, with all the time in the world to pursue the things I never had the time to pursue because I had to work 40 hours a week. That all changed when in my late 30s I was able to work only part time from home, and even THEN, I still did not have the time to do a lot of things I've always wanted to do. One of them is to learn conversational Spanish. Another is to learn to sight read sheet music for the piano. Another is to take a therapy dog to hospitals twice a week to comfort people. The list goes on and on. How a person could continue working a full time job well into their 90s is one of life's great mysteries -- unless they truly need the money.

Comment: As near as I can tell a problem with pre-build UP forecasts is they never realistically factored in all various costs to potential users. Things like time cost to schlep to and from stations, along with possible monetary costs. Potential for appearance costs on wet, snowy and hot days.  Potential navigational issues for visitors; so much easier to jump in a taxi or limo and relax. 
Taxi time costs are competitive or even better for much of the day from most locations.  25 minutes for about 25km is not 'express' in my train books. 
Taxi dollar costs were competitive with two pax, and better with three than the original $27 fare. 
Original promotional BS of comparing UP Express to London's Heathrow Express were blind to all the foregoing and scale differences. On the subject of scale, I wonder if those little UP trains could be lengthened if the project were ever a success? Or are there station restrictions.  If so, are they capable of frequency increases?

Comment: The FPTP system may not be "the best" - but none of the others are a clear improvement. In any multi-party election the majority who end up governing will most likely be under 50% of voter input. This is a purely mathematical artifact and does not imply an undemocratic process. The far deeper issue is general fiscal irrepsonsibility ( Ontariowe ), a public sector that has enough political power to vote itself into into the line up for membership in the sunshine list. Never mind disinterested uninformed voters and the usual media circus.

As for any proportional system - such complexities would merely serve to obfuscate clear responsibility. And then there was the lesson of the Weimar Republic - all very democratic and full of good intentions - then gamed by the NAZI Party. No thanks.

The Liberal effort in this direction was quite amateurish - the "survey" a piece of embarrassing fluff devoid of any clear options. So FPTP remains, and we have more important problems to solve.

Comment: Many Canadians need to get over their visceral anti-Americanism. Although the partnership between Canada and the United States is sometimes strained, there is still a friendship between our countries that is almost unequaled in the world. We must not allow misplaced national pride to blind us from the undeniable fact that we need American military protection for our country's survival. It is a shame that past and current prime ministers have been willing to sacrifice Canada's defense needs on the altar of political expediency. Although the United States would most likely defend Canada in the event that it is targeted by a foreign aggressor, the best way to guarantee that we are protected is to enter into a joint missile-defense agreement without further delay. Rather than benefit from US military protection by default, Canada needs to pull its own weight within a mutual defense pact.  Puerile political posturing will not save us if the nuclear missiles start flying.

Comment: The greatest risk to pension plans is interest rates, certainly a large pooled pension has economies of scale but low interest rates are a big drag on pensions.  When you "shop with my employer" (I am a small business owner), you have the choice of where you shop.  If I, as ABC company match my employees' 13% instead of the 3% they do at XYZ company, then I have to charge more to pay that benefit and hope that customers will be willing to pay more to buy my product or service instead of buying from an offshored company paying their employees pennies.  This free market dynamic does not exist to keep teachers pensions in check so we as taxpayers are spending more each year to maintain teachers DB plans.  In essence, the average taxpayer is now contributing to teachers pensions instead of their own, while the average teacher now works 26 years at retirement instead of 29 just a couple of decades ago.  See https://www.otpp.com/corporate/plan-funding/funding-considerations

Comment: Fairly decent article, but you got the world war 2 thing dead wrong. World War 2 was decidedly good for the economy - but just about anything else would have been even better. What world war 2 did - was to finally force the government to stop listening to idiotic austrian economists (read pseudo-scientific cultists) and actually do the thing you have to do to end a depression: spend lots of government money (because nobody else is spending anything) and it's the only way to turn the deflation around.

The Pope and the press corps were amazed! Donald Trump could actually walk on water!
Speculation immediately began as to how ABC, CNN, NBC, The Washington Post and New York Times would report this miraculous event to the rest of the world.

Comment: If only that were true. Business will charge whatever price the market will bear. It's not always related to cost recovery. Look at the banks nickel and diming us with service charges. Their profit continues to escalate. There are many examples of business that, in theory, should be subject to competition but somehow manage to avoid this part of capitalist theory. Gas companies are another example.

A big problem with customer/business relationship is the customer doesn't always have good information to compare prices and services. What service charges are there? What do those services include? It's exhausting sometimes to try and wade through all the info when the presentation differs so much from business to business. Sometimes the fine print doesn't even cover what you need to know. Who has time for all that, all the time? 

Look at the little booklet of info the airlines provide re your rights as a flier. A whole truckload of stuff they would rather you didn't know.
